dt.t: a heart attack or other cardiac {wi}event{/wi}

dt: {bc}any of the contests in a program of sports

dt.t: in the {wi}event{/wi} that I am not there, call the house

dt: {bc}the final outcome or determination of a legal action

{bc}the fundamental entity of observed physical reality represented by a point designated by three coordinates of place and one of time in the space-time continuum postulated by the theory of relativity
{bc}a subset of the possible outcomes of an experiment

pt: {sc}occurrence{/sc} {sc}event{/sc} {sc}incident{/sc} {sc}episode{/sc} {sc}circumstance{/sc} mean something that happens or takes place. {sc}occurrence{/sc} may apply to a happening without intent, volition, or plan.

pt.t: an encounter that was a chance {it}occurrence{/it}

pt: {sc}event{/sc} usually implies an occurrence of some importance and frequently one having antecedent cause.
{sc}incident{/sc} suggests an occurrence of brief duration or secondary importance.
{sc}episode{/sc} stresses the distinctiveness or apartness of an incident.

pt.t: a brief romantic {it}episode{/it} in a life devoted to work

pt: {sc}circumstance{/sc} implies a specific detail attending an action or event as part of its setting or background.

et: Middle French or Latin; Middle French, from Latin {it}eventus{/it}, from {it}evenire{/it} to happen, from {it}e-{/it} + {it}venire{/it} to come {ma}{mat|come|}{/ma}
